title: 113_hr2829
content: The Act may be cited as the "Restoring Important Voter Eligibility Requirements to States Act of 2013". Congress enacted the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 to promote the rights of eligible citizens of the United States to vote and increase voter registration. The Act also aims to protect the integrity of the electoral process. The purpose of the Act is to ensure that voting procedures for Federal elections align with the National Voter Registration Act of 1993, preventing ineligible individuals from participating in such elections. Expanded requirements for voter registration application forms are outlined in Section 3 of the Act. The National Voter Registration Act of 1993 is amended to require applicants to affirmatively state that they meet eligibility requirements as a condition of acceptance for motor vehicle driver's licenses and other voter registration agencies. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to include a statement on registration forms specifying that failure to check "yes" to certain questions will result in the application not being accepted. Additionally, the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 is amended to require applicants to affirmatively state their eligibility as a condition for acceptance of motor vehicle driver's licenses and voter registration. The National Voter Registration Act of 1993 is amended to include a statement on registration forms warning applicants that providing false information constitutes perjury, with specific penalties outlined. Additionally, forms provided by other voter registration agencies are also updated to include similar warnings about the consequences of providing false information. The National Voter Registration Act of 1993 is amended to include warnings on registration forms about the consequences of providing false information, including penalties for perjury. Additionally, mail registration forms under the Help America Vote Act of 2002 are updated to reflect similar warnings. The National Voter Registration Act of 1993 is amended to include warnings on registration forms about the consequences of providing false information, including penalties for perjury. This includes informing individuals about the specific fines and imprisonment terms for committing perjury by providing false answers on the form. Nothing in the amendments prohibits the inclusion of this information on voter registration forms by the Election Assistance Commission or any State or local election official. The National Voter Registration Act of 1993 prohibits including information on voter registration forms about sanctions for providing false information. SEC. 4. VERIFICATION OF INFORMATION PROVIDED BY APPLICANTS FOR VOTER REGISTRATION. SEC. 4 amends the National Voter Registration Act to require States to verify the information provided by individuals applying to vote in Federal elections. Verification methods are outlined to ensure accuracy in voter registration applications. The National Voter Registration Act is amended to allow States to verify voter registration information provided by applicants, including requiring documentary evidence of eligibility, such as U.S. citizenship. Federal officials are also required to provide information for verification purposes. The National Voter Registration Act is amended to allow States to verify voter registration information provided by applicants. Federal officials must enter into agreements with State election officials to verify applicant eligibility for voting in Federal elections within 30 days of a request. Additionally, the Act clarifies information provided by the Commissioner of Social Security by including the location and date of birth. The amendments made by this Act will apply to elections occurring after a 1-year period from the enactment date.
